citeinfo.title: DNA fingerprinting of Southern Mule Deer (Odocoileus hemionus fuliginatus) to determine movement across California State Route 67

descript.abstract: The goal of this project was to primarily assess east-west connectivity across Route 67 and secondarily, north-south connectivity across Scripps Poway Parkway and Poway Road, two highly trafficked roads to the west of Route 67. We collected deer scat piles from both sides of these crossings in spring between March and June of 2015, and again in fall throughout October 2015. Collected pellets were extracted and amplified using protocols and loci developed by Bohonak and Mitelberg (2014). DNA fingerprinting results were used to investigate mule deer movement in the region directly by identifying individuals which had been captured multiple times throughout the study period. We also assessed movement indirectly through pedigree reconstruction and population structure analyses. This file contains 126 deer scat piles and the genotypes obtained at 15 microsatellite markers and one sex specific genetic marker. These represented 71 unique individual genotypes (45 females, 26 males) with 9 recapture events and 46 resampling events (defined as scat piles collected at the same location within one week of each other and matching the same unique genotype).
descript.purpose: Data were collected to assess movement and gene flow of Southern Mule Deer across State Route 67.
descript.supplinf: Scat piles were collected by hand from multiple locations along California State Route 67 between Lakeside and Poway and were extracted and genotyped following the screening protocol described in Bohonak and Mitelberg (2014). This included screening at 15 nuclear microsatellite loci and one sex specific marker. Briefly, all scat piles were initially genotyped twice at all loci; these genotypes were analyzed with RELIOTYPE (Miller et al., 2002), a software which implements a maximum likelihood algorithm to assesses the reliability of the multilocus genotype based on allele frequencies [we used allele frequencies from the Bohonak and Mitelberg’s (2014) dataset], and recommends a replication strategy for those samples failing to pass the 99.49% reliability criteria. At this point, all samples requiring more than 6 PCR replicates were discarded. The remainder were genotyped again (according to RELIOTYPE recommendations) and run through RELIOTYPE a second time, following which all samples failing to yield a reliable genotype were discarded from the data set. Finally, GIMLET 1.3.3 (Valiere, 2002) was used to reconstruct consensus genotypes for all scat piles with reliable DNA fingerprints. The consensus genotypes for all scat piles with scat piles with reliable DNA fingerprints were grouped by genotype, with missing alleles considered as any other alleles. Within this set of scat piles, we identified unique individual genotypes using GIMLET’s group by genotype algorithm. The remaining scat piles were further sorted into two categories: either they were resampling events resulting from repeated sampling of the same individual’s scat piles at the same site and time, or they were true recaptures of the individual at a different site and/or time. All scat piles collected within a week of each other and matching the same unique genotype were considered re-sampling events; in these cases, all resampling events of an individual mule deer were reduced to one capture event with the first scat pile processed in the laboratory serving as a representative of that capture event. Bohonak, A., Mitelberg, A. 2014. Social Structure and Genetic Connectivity in the Southern Mule Deer: Implications for Management. San Diego State University. San Diego: Report Prepared for California Department of Fish and Game. Miller, C.R., Joyce, P., Waits, L.P. 2002. Assessing allelic dropout and genotype reliability using maximum likelihood. Genetics 160, 357-366. Valière, N. 2002. GIMLET: a computer program for analyzing genetic individual identification. Molecular Ecology Notes 2, 377-379.

dataqual.complete: Data set is considered complete for the information presented, as described in the abstract. Users are advised to read the rest of the metadata record carefully for additional details.

enttyp.enttypd: Table containing attribute information associated with the data set.

attr.attrdef: Unique individual identification code
unique identifier for individual scat piles analyzed.
Collection seasons scat collections took place (Spring or Fall)
Collection Date: Month, Date, Year of scat collection

Re-sampling events are defined as instances where several scat piles were collected for the same mule deer within a week's time at the same site (e.g. MD809 was sampled twice on the same day with scat pile SP809 and scat pile SP810).

edom.edomvd: indicates that there were several samples

attr.attrdef: collection latitude recorded in the field with a handheld GPS for each scat pile collected. Datum = NAD83.
collection longitude recorded in the field with a handheld GPS for each scat pile collected. Datum = NAD83.
Sex = F positive for female genetic marker; M = positive for male genetic marker.

edom.edomvd: F positive for female genetic marker

attr.attrdef: Genotype (Locus B – V) = Per locus genotype coded as 3 digit sequence lengths. First 3 digits represent 1st allele, second 3 digits represent 2nd allele for each of 15 microsatellite loci. Missing data coded as 000000

overview.eaover: Scat piles yielding a reliable genotype (99.49% reliability, as determined by the software RELIOTYPE) arranged by collection date. Recapture events are instances were the same individual mule deer was sampled on two different days (denoted with grey rows; e.g. MD808, who was captured on 4/6/15 with scat pile SP808 was recaptured on 10/8/15 with scat pile SP909). Re-sampling events are listed at the end of the table and are defined as instances where several scat piles were collected for the same mule deer within a week's time at the same site (e.g. MD809 was sampled twice on the same day with scat pile SP809 and scat pile SP810). Missing data at a microsatellite locus is coded as 000000.
overview.eadetcit: The entity and attribute information was generated by the individual and/or agency identified as the originator of the data set. Please review the rest of the metadata record for additional details and information.

distinfo.distliab: Unless otherwise stated, all data, metadata and related materials are considered to satisfy the quality standards relative to the purpose for which the data were collected. Although these data and associated metadata have been reviewed for accuracy and completeness and approved for release by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the display or utility of the data on any other system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. Any use of trade, firm, or product names is for descriptive purposes only and does not imply endorsement by the U.S. Government.
